intro: Pinanga palustris, commonly known as the swamp bamboo, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Araceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems that often form dense clumps. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in a spadix, typical of the arum family. Its leaves are long and narrow, often emerging from the base of the plant. Pinanga palustris thrives in wetland environments, making it an important component of swamp and marsh ecosystems.
